answers.answer: Wahooo! GREAT news!  Keep us posted!

Congratulations!!  I am so happy to hear your pregnancy is progressing smoothly.Try not to worry to much about the first trimester screen and the higher odds of trisonomy 21.  My first trimester screen came back with 1:13 odds of downs syndrome.  I was worried and opted for amnio.  I am not in any way, shape or form telling you that amnio is the way to go, that is a highly personal decision, but for me it turned out to be the right one.  The procedure itself was not painful at all, and everything went smoothly.  It came back showing my son was just fine and I am now able to relax and enjoy the rest of this pregnancy.The reality is that even though our odds of downs syndrome are higher (I will be 41 at delivery), very few babies are actually born with it.  In fact, in two years of being on these boards I have met one women whose baby actually had chromosonal abnormalities ( I am not including those that miscarried, just those whose babies went full term) and it was something other then 21.  The other women I have met on MedHelp that had DS babies were in their 20's and early 30's.I wish you a happy and healthy pregnancy, and look forward to reading your updates!!  Congratulations again!!  Amanda

What a wonderful update!  Thank you for sharing.  The odds are so deceitful as far as looking at it in the ratios versus the percentages.  Like your doctor said, when the ratio goes past 1:10, it only increases by small increments.  I like hearing the 97.5% more than the 1:40.  It just makes more sense to me.I hope that the rest of your pregnancy is uneventful.  I had a wonderful pregnancy at 44 and the nice thing about it was my doctor treated me just like I was any other pregnant woman although afterwards he told me that he kept a little closer eye on me than he would had I been 20 years younger.  That only made me feel better.It sounds like you have an excellent doctor - jen
That is WONDERFUL!!!!  So excited for you, & your hubby!  ENJOY being pregnant, I LOVED it!  It's for such a short time & it is an amazing experience ;)
What wonderful news! And glad you have a doctor who knows how to explain statistics properly. He's a winner!
Such inspiration for the rest of us in our 40s ttc!  congrats and enjoy your pregnancy!
Congratulations on your wonderful news.  You inspire me to keep trying and your doctor sounds like a winner.

WOW!!!  Congratulations!!  I'm so happy for you!  I'm 41 and delivering at 42.  I'm 15 weeks tomorrow and all is going well.  I can't believe I'm almost 4 months along!  I see my OB on Sept 10, but when I saw my family doc on Monday I got to hear the heartbeat.  It was so cool.  All the best!  Jo

Oh yeah, I forgot to mention that I stopped reading all of the doom & gloom about being pg in your 40s and it really helped.  I'm doing all of the screenings because I know I'm at higher risk of chromosomal disorders, but I committed to the baby without knowing the results, even though it has been the cause of some underlying stress.  Because of the increased risk of gestational diabetes, I've been trying to avoid it by cutting out refined flours & sugars, etc (i.e., managing by diet) and light exercise.  All we can do is take care of ourselves and make the best decisions given the information.  Congratulations again.  Jo

question: Hi All.....first up - thank you for your overwhelming support, i appreciate all the well wishes, notes and prayers, thank you!  Went to obgyn yesterday.  All is well.  i am officially 9 weeks 2 days pregnant today.  Did ultrasound and saw and heard heartbeat - amazing.  i have to return in 3 weeks for him to check the baby's nuchal translucency (nt) and do first trimester blood screening.  he said at my age the risk of having a baby with DS or other chromosomal abnorms is one in forty (as opposed to one in two hundred for a 24 year old).  he also said this averages only about 2.5% chance which means i do have a 97.5% chance of a healthy baby, it depends on how i want to look at it.  He said he will monitor for diabetes which runs in my family as well as heart defects (both my older sister and I were born with a hole in our heart (asd) and we each had successful surgery in adulthood to repair). my iron was slightly low which would explain some of my endless fatigue, so he put me on iron supplements.  other than this i am happy to report the baby and i are healthy.  Best wishes to all other pregnant older first time (and repeat) moms.  to those still trying i am sending positive thoughts your way.  Until my next update, take care.  Hazel
title: UPDATE 44 AND PREGGERS
